mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">&nbsp;11th, 2015 in Liege (Belgium). The Symposium is organized by the&nbsp;</span><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">von Karman Institute for Fluid Dynamics and the University of Liege.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;"><br style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;"><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">We invite researchers to present their work on fundamental science and&nbsp;</span><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">technology research related nanosatellites in the beautiful city of&nbsp;</span><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">Liege with a long history of space flight and close to the beautiful&nbsp;</span><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">Ardenne mountains. font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">studies of CubeSat components and satellite systems to scientific&nbsp;</span><span style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: normal;">operations of CubSat constellations and related ground segments.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: arial, sans-serif; The CubeSat payloads have been provided through NASA's&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/heo/home/CubeSats_initiative.html" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/heo/home/CubeSats_initiative.html" target="_blank">Educational Launch of Nanosatellites (ELaNa)</a> program. There is a 3 minute launch window starting at 6:20am Pacific Time. Below is information about each CubeSat including tracking information where available and links to developers' websites. For launch status, see&nbsp;<a href="http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/01/28/d370-mission-status-center/" mce_href="http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/01/28/d370-mission-status-center/" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now's mission status page</a>.</p> <table border="2" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2"> <tbody>  <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">1</td> <td>FIREBIRD-2</td> <td>Montana State University, University of New Hampshire, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Aerospace Corp.</td> <td>1.5U (x2)</td> <td> <p>Flight Unit 3: 437.405 MHz</p> <p>Flight Unit 4: 437.230 MHz</p> <p><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #000000; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;" mce_style="font-size: x-small;">19.2k baud GMSK AX.25 packet at 60 second period. Each beacon is two separate packets about 1 second apart.</span></span><br /></p> </td> <td><a href="https://ssel.montana.edu/" mce_href="https://ssel.montana.edu/" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></td> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/fb2_100.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/fb2_100.jpg" alt=""><br /></td> </tr>    <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">2</td> <td>GRIFEX</td> <td>University of Michigan / NASA JPL</td> <td>3U</td> <td>437.485 MHz, &lt;1W GMSK, AX.25 9600 baud, 10 sec period</td> <td> <p><a href="http://exploration.engin.umich.edu/blog/?page_id=2498" mce_href="http://exploration.engin.umich.edu/blog/?page_id=2498" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></p> </td> <td> <p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/grifex100.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/grifex100.jpg" alt=""><br /></p> </td> </tr>  <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">3</td> <td>ExoCube</td> <td>Cal Poly, PolySat</td> <td>3U</td> <td>437.270MHz, 9600 baud AX.25 FSK, NRZI+SCRAMBLED, Morse Code spells out "X03" every 45 seconds<br /></td> <td><a href="http://polysat.calpoly.edu/launched-missions/cp8-ipex/exocube-tracking/" mce_href="http://polysat.calpoly.edu/launched-missions/cp8-ipex/exocube-tracking/" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></td> <td> <p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/exocube_120.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/exocube_120.jpg" alt=""><br /></p></td></tr></tbody></table> <p>For those of you supporting us on launch day, don't forget to join the IRC channel. Information about the channel can be found at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators" mce_href="http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators" target="_blank">http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators</a>.</p><p>Preliminary TLEs (updated 1/31/15 for actual liftoff time):</p><pre>FIREBIRD-2 1 99991U          15031.59861111 -.00003570  00000-0 -19504-3 0 00001 2 99991 099.0984 037.3071 0163136 342.7180 150.8323 15.03559600000011 GRIFEX 1 99992U          15031.59861111 -.00003597  00000-0 -20054-3 0 00003 2 99992 099.0980 037.3077 0161468 342.2744 151.4119 15.03089438000018 EXOCUBE 1 99993U          15031.59861111 -.00003538  00000-0 -19750-3 0 00000 2 99993 099.0978 037.3072 0161500 341.7803 151.9355 15.03037792000011 </pre><p><br /></p><p><span style="font-size: large;" mce_style="font-size: large;"><b><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0);" mce_style="color: #000000;"><u>ELaNa-10 on NASA EDGE Webcast</u>:</span></b></span></p><p>Live NASA TV launch coverage of the countdown begins at 4 am PST (7 am EST) and also on the NASA Web at<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/smap" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/smap">http://www.nasa.gov/smap</a> or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p> <p>Coverage concludes after SMAP spacecraft separation from the Delta II and solar array deployment has been initiated. NASA's launch blog will continue coverage through CubeSat separation.</p> <p>NASA EDGE will webcast&nbsp;<u>Part 1</u> of launch coverage with live interviews at 5:20 am PST (8:20 am EST) and&nbsp;<u>Part 2</u>&nbsp;ELaNa X CubeSat coverage with live interviews at 7:25 am PST(10:25 am EST).</p> <p>It can be accessed at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge" mce_href="http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge">http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge</a></p> <p>The program will also be carried live on the NASA Education channel&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p> <p>A post-launch news conference will be held at 9 am PST (12 pm EST) and carried live on NASA Television&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p></summary>   <content type="html"><p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/elana10_patch_300.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/elana10_patch_300.jpg" alt="">&nbsp;<br /></p> <p>Four CubeSats successfully launched aboard a Delta II rocket with the NASA SMAP primary payload from Vandenberg AFB in California on January 31st, 2015. The CubeSat payloads have been provided through NASA's&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/heo/home/CubeSats_initiative.html" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/heo/home/CubeSats_initiative.html" target="_blank">Educational Launch of Nanosatellites (ELaNa)</a> program. There is a 3 minute launch window starting at 6:20am Pacific Time. Below is information about each CubeSat including tracking information where available and links to developers' websites. For launch status, see&nbsp;<a href="http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/01/28/d370-mission-status-center/" mce_href="http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/01/28/d370-mission-status-center/" target="_blank">Spaceflight Now's mission status page</a>.</p> <table border="2" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2"> <tbody>  <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">1</td> <td>FIREBIRD-2</td> <td>Montana State University, University of New Hampshire, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Aerospace Corp.</td> <td>1.5U (x2)</td> <td> <p>Flight Unit 3: 437.405 MHz</p> <p>Flight Unit 4: 437.230 MHz</p> <p><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: normal;" mce_style="color: #000000; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;" mce_style="font-size: x-small;">19.2k baud GMSK AX.25 packet at 60 second period. Each beacon is two separate packets about 1 second apart.</span></span><br /></p> </td> <td><a href="https://ssel.montana.edu/" mce_href="https://ssel.montana.edu/" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></td> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/fb2_100.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/fb2_100.jpg" alt=""><br /></td> </tr>    <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">2</td> <td>GRIFEX</td> <td>University of Michigan / NASA JPL</td> <td>3U</td> <td>437.485 MHz, &lt;1W GMSK, AX.25 9600 baud, 10 sec period</td> <td> <p><a href="http://exploration.engin.umich.edu/blog/?page_id=2498" mce_href="http://exploration.engin.umich.edu/blog/?page_id=2498" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></p> </td> <td> <p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/grifex100.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/grifex100.jpg" alt=""><br /></p> </td> </tr>  <tr> <td style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;">3</td> <td>ExoCube</td> <td>Cal Poly, PolySat</td> <td>3U</td> <td>437.270MHz, 9600 baud AX.25 FSK, NRZI+SCRAMBLED, Morse Code spells out "X03" every 45 seconds<br /></td> <td><a href="http://polysat.calpoly.edu/launched-missions/cp8-ipex/exocube-tracking/" mce_href="http://polysat.calpoly.edu/launched-missions/cp8-ipex/exocube-tracking/" target="_blank" style="">More Info</a></td> <td> <p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><img src="images/stories/ELaNa10/exocube_120.jpg" mce_src="images/stories/ELaNa10/exocube_120.jpg" alt=""><br /></p></td></tr></tbody></table> <p>For those of you supporting us on launch day, don't forget to join the IRC channel. Information about the channel can be found at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators" mce_href="http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators" target="_blank">http://www.cubesat.org/index.php/collaborate/ground-operators</a>.</p><p>Preliminary TLEs (updated 1/31/15 for actual liftoff time):</p><pre>FIREBIRD-2 1 99991U          15031.59861111 -.00003570  00000-0 -19504-3 0 00001 2 99991 099.0984 037.3071 0163136 342.7180 150.8323 15.03559600000011 GRIFEX 1 99992U          15031.59861111 -.00003597  00000-0 -20054-3 0 00003 2 99992 099.0980 037.3077 0161468 342.2744 151.4119 15.03089438000018 EXOCUBE 1 99993U          15031.59861111 -.00003538  00000-0 -19750-3 0 00000 2 99993 099.0978 037.3072 0161500 341.7803 151.9355 15.03037792000011 </pre><p><br /></p><p><span style="font-size: large;" mce_style="font-size: large;"><b><span style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0);" mce_style="color: #000000;"><u>ELaNa-10 on NASA EDGE Webcast</u>:</span></b></span></p><p>Live NASA TV launch coverage of the countdown begins at 4 am PST (7 am EST) and also on the NASA Web at<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/smap" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/smap">http://www.nasa.gov/smap</a> or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p> <p>Coverage concludes after SMAP spacecraft separation from the Delta II and solar array deployment has been initiated. NASA's launch blog will continue coverage through CubeSat separation.</p> <p>NASA EDGE will webcast&nbsp;<u>Part 1</u> of launch coverage with live interviews at 5:20 am PST (8:20 am EST) and&nbsp;<u>Part 2</u>&nbsp;ELaNa X CubeSat coverage with live interviews at 7:25 am PST(10:25 am EST).</p> <p>It can be accessed at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge" mce_href="http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge">http://www.ustream.tv/nasaedge</a></p> <p>The program will also be carried live on the NASA Education channel&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p> <p>A post-launch news conference will be held at 9 am PST (12 pm EST) and carried live on NASA Television&nbsp;<a href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv" mce_href="http://www.nasa.gov/ntv">http://www.nasa.gov/ntv</a></p></content>  </entry>  <entry>   <title>Congressional legislation to remove satellites from ITAR</title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.weww.cubesat.org/index.php/component/content/article/113-congressional-legislation-to-remove-satellites-from-itar"/>   <published>2011-12-23T21:00:17Z</published>   <updated>2011-12-23T21:00:17Z</updated>   <id>http://www.weww.cubesat.org/index.php/component/content/article/113-congressional-legislation-to-remove-satellites-from-itar</id>   <author>    <name>Cubesat</name>   <email>cubesat@gmail.com</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><b><b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">Congressional Legislation to Remove Satellites from ITAR<br /></span></b></b></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;"></span></span></b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">The House of Representatives in the U.S. Senate recently passed a bill, H.R. 3288, with a clause to remove ITAR restrictions on commercial satellites. The specific wording for the purpose of the bill:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;"><i>To authorize the President to remove commercial satellites and related components<br />from the United States Munitions List subject to certain restrictions,<br />and for other purposes.</i></span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">Full test of the Bill can be found in PDF here:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><a mce_href="http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf" href="http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf"><span mce_style="font-size: small;" style="font-size: small;">http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf</span></a><br mce_bogus="1"></p><p style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: large;" style="font-size: large;">Status of the bill:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><a mce_href="http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288" href="http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288">http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288</a></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;">This bill only pertains to commercial satellites, and does not include scientific or educational in its current form. Make your voices heard and please write to your Representatives for the inclusion of these terms. Removing educational, scientific, and commercial satellites from ITAR control will help foster the international small satellite community. </span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;">Representatives Howard Berman, Don Manzullo, Adam Smith, Mike Coffman, Dutch Ruppersberger, Rob Bishop, Gerry Connolly, Jason Chaffetz, and Martin Heinrich introduced the bill, and are the best people to contact regarding updates and changes.</span></p></summary>   <content type="html"><p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><b><b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">Congressional Legislation to Remove Satellites from ITAR<br /></span></b></b></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;"></span></span></b><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">The House of Representatives in the U.S. Senate recently passed a bill, H.R. 3288, with a clause to remove ITAR restrictions on commercial satellites. The specific wording for the purpose of the bill:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;" mce_style="text-align: center;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;"><i>To authorize the President to remove commercial satellites and related components<br />from the United States Munitions List subject to certain restrictions,<br />and for other purposes.</i></span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;" style="font-size: 13.5pt; font-family: &quot;Helvetica&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;;">Full test of the Bill can be found in PDF here:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><a mce_href="http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf" href="http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf"><span mce_style="font-size: small;" style="font-size: small;">http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3288ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3288ih.pdf</span></a><br mce_bogus="1"></p><p style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: large;" style="font-size: large;">Status of the bill:</span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><a mce_href="http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288" href="http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288">http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-3288</a></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;">This bill only pertains to commercial satellites, and does not include scientific or educational in its current form. Make your voices heard and please write to your Representatives for the inclusion of these terms. Removing educational, scientific, and commercial satellites from ITAR control will help foster the international small satellite community. </span></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;" mce_style="text-align: left;"><span mce_style="font-size: medium;" style="font-size: medium;">Representatives Howard Berman, Don Manzullo, Adam Smith, Mike Coffman, Dutch Ruppersberger, Rob Bishop, Gerry Connolly, Jason Chaffetz, and Martin Heinrich introduced the bill, and are the best people to contact regarding updates and changes.</span></p></content>  </entry>  <entry>   <title>NASA Announces Candidates For CubeSat Space Missions</title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.weww.cubesat.org/index.php/component/content/article/92-elana"/>   <published>2011-02-15T04:45:37Z</published>   <updated>2011-02-15T04:45:37Z</updated>   <id>http://www.weww.cubesat.org/index.php/component/content/article/92-elana</id>   <summary type="html"><p style="text-align: left;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000033; font-family: VERDANA,ARIAL,HELVETICA,sans-serif; font-size: x-large;"><strong><strong><strong><strong>NASA Announces Candidates for CubeSat Space Missions</strong></strong></strong></strong></span></span></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong><img src="images/stories/elana%20logo%20300.jpg" border="0" width="150" height="171" style="border: 0pt none; vertical-align: top;" /></strong></p> <p>WASHINGTON -- NASA has selected 20 small satellites to fly as auxiliary  cargo aboard rockets planned to launch in 2011 and 2012. The proposed  CubeSats come from a high school in Virginia, universities across the  country, NASA field centers and Department of Defense organizations. <br /> <br /> CubeSats are a class of research spacecraft called nanosatellites. The  cube-shaped satellites are approximately four inches long, have a volume  of about one quart and weigh 2.2 pounds or less. <br /> <br /> The  selections are from the second round of the CubeSat Launch Initiative.  The satellites are expected to conduct technology demonstrations,  educational research or science missions. The selected spacecraft are  eligible for flight after final negotiations when an opportunity arises.  The satellites come from the following organizations, which include the  first high school proposal selected for a CubeSat flight: <br /> <br /> -- Air Force Research Lab, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio <br /> -- Drexel University, Philadelphia <br /> -- NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md. (two CubeSats) <br /> -- NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif. (two CubeSats) <br /> -- Naval Research Lab, Washington (two CubeSats) <br /> -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology <br /> -- Morehead State University, Morehead, Ky. <br /> -- The Planetary Society, Pasadena, in partnership with NASA's Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, Calif. <br /> -- Space and Missile Defense Command, Huntsville, Ala. <br /> -- St. Louis University, St. Louis, Miss. <br /> -- Thomas Jefferson High School, Alexandria, Va. <br /> -- University of Colorado <br /> -- University of Hawaii <br /> -- University of Louisiana, Lafayette <br /> -- University of New Mexico <br /> -- U.S. Military Academy <br /> -- U.S. Naval Academy <br /> <br /> The first CubeSats to be carried on an expendable vehicle for the  agency's Launch Services Program will comprise NASA's Educational Launch  of Nanosatellite, or ELaNa, mission. ELaNa will fly on the Glory  mission scheduled to lift off on Feb. 23. The 12 CubeSat payloads  selected from the first round of the CubeSat Launch Initiative will have  launch opportunities beginning later this year. <br /> <br /> For information about NASA's CubeSat Launch Initiative program, visit: <br /> <br /></p> <p align="center"><a href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/somd/home/CubeSats_initiative.html">http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/somd/home/CubeSats_initiative.html</a></p> <p><br /> For information about NASA and agency programs, visit: <br /> <br /></p> <p align="center"><a href="http://www.nasa.gov/">http://www.nasa.gov</a></p> <p style="text-align: left;">(article by NASA)</p></summary>   <content type="html"><p style="text-align: left;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000033; font-family: VERDANA,ARIAL,HELVETICA,sans-serif; font-size: x-large;"><strong><strong><strong><strong>NASA Announces Candidates for CubeSat Space Missions</strong></strong></strong></strong></span></span></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong><img src="images/stories/elana%20logo%20300.jpg" border="0" width="150" height="171" style="border: 0pt none; vertical-align: top;" /></strong></p> <p>WASHINGTON -- NASA has selected 20 small satellites to fly as auxiliary  cargo aboard rockets planned to launch in 2011 and 2012. The proposed  CubeSats come from a high school in Virginia, universities across the  country, NASA field centers and Department of Defense organizations. <br /> <br /> CubeSats are a class of research spacecraft called nanosatellites. The  cube-shaped satellites are approximately four inches long, have a volume  of about one quart and weigh 2.2 pounds or less. <br /> <br /> The  selections are from the second round of the CubeSat Launch Initiative.  The satellites are expected to conduct technology demonstrations,  educational research or science missions. The selected spacecraft are  eligible for flight after final negotiations when an opportunity arises.  The satellites come from the following organizations, which include the  first high school proposal selected for a CubeSat flight: <br /> <br /> -- Air Force Research Lab, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio <br /> -- Drexel University, Philadelphia <br /> -- NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md. (two CubeSats) <br /> -- NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif. (two CubeSats) <br /> -- Naval Research Lab, Washington (two CubeSats) <br /> -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology <br /> -- Morehead State University, Morehead, Ky. <br /> -- The Planetary Society, Pasadena, in partnership with NASA's Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, Calif. <br /> -- Space and Missile Defense Command, Huntsville, Ala. <br /> -- St. Louis University, St. Louis, Miss. <br /> -- Thomas Jefferson High School, Alexandria, Va. <br /> -- University of Colorado <br /> -- University of Hawaii <br /> -- University of Louisiana, Lafayette <br /> -- University of New Mexico <br /> -- U.S. Military Academy <br /> -- U.S. Naval Academy <br /> <br /> The first CubeSats to be carried on an expendable vehicle for the  agency's Launch Services Program will comprise NASA's Educational Launch  of Nanosatellite, or ELaNa, mission. The 12 CubeSat payloads  selected from the first round of the CubeSat Launch Initiative will have  launch opportunities beginning later this year. <br /> <br /> For information about NASA's CubeSat Launch Initiative program, visit: <br /> <br /></p> <p align="center"><a href="http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/somd/home/CubeSats_initiative.html">http://www.nasa.gov/directorates/somd/home/CubeSats_initiative.html</a></p> <p><br /> For information about NASA and agency programs, visit: <br /> <br /></p> <p align="center"><a href="http://www.nasa.gov/">http://www.nasa.gov</a></p> <p style="text-align: left;">(article by NASA)</p></content>  </entry> </feed>
